title: المتحف المصري الكبير: ما قصة أكبر متحف للحضارة الفرعونية في العالم وما أبرز مقتنياته؟

segments.text: This is a podcast worth paying attention to from BBC Arabic News, and I am Mais Baqi.
Joining us from Alexandria is Dr. Hussein Abdel Basir,
the former general supervisor of the Grand Egyptian Museum.
He is currently the director of the Antiquities Museum at the Library of Alexandria.
Welcome to the podcast that deserves your attention.
Hello and welcome to you and all the listeners and viewers.
Dr. Hussein, you are now one of the people who oversaw the management of the Grand Egyptian Museum.
How do you feel about the official opening of the project?
It's a feeling of happiness and pride, just like any father or mother receiving a new child, for us the Grand Egyptian Museum.
And for me specifically, it's like welcoming my first child.
Doctor, tell me about the phase you were in while managing this project.
As I read, the story of the Grand Egyptian Museum began with the foundation stone being laid in 2002.
So, after all these years, what caused the delay?
Of course, the project started with a dream and an idea, and as I mentioned, the foundation stone was laid in 2002.
As we open this year in 2025, why all this delay?
The delay, of course, was due to various reasons; we gathered a very large number of artifacts.
Especially significant artifacts from various regions of the country.
In addition to the artifacts from the Pharaohs and the royal Ankh-Morpork that we began to plan and transfer to the project.
The economic and political conditions the country was going through also played a role; we had, of course, the January events as you know.
All of these factors did affect the work a bit; it progressed slowly, but it did not stop.
All these matters are what extended the duration.
So, Doctor, did the length of the execution period affect the architectural design of the museum? Were there any additional programs or updates made during this time?
Of course, we can say that the basic plan of the project has not changed.
However, there were some modifications to this project and some minor additions to ensure it aligns with the Egyptian environment and society.
But these are things we can say are minor and haven't really affected the project much.
However, the overall plan that needs to be established is what has been worked on, and the beautiful thing about it is the project built around the pyramids.
I mean, if we look at the layout of the pyramids, we find that the point from which it starts radiates three rays.
The first ray reaches the peak of King Khufu's pyramid.
The ray in the middle reaches the peak of the second pyramid, that of King Khafre.
And the last and third ray reaches the peak of the third pyramid belonging to King Menkaure.
So, the choice of this location is considered very important, and its connection to the pyramids is something truly magnificent.
The idea of the pyramids and the concept of sunlight in ancient Egypt and its modernization in modern Egypt.
It is a philosophical perspective on this issue.
And even the doctor, according to the information available, regarding the architectural design.
Visitors inside the museum will be able to see the three pyramids in the Giza area.
Of course, this is the goal, as Aref mentioned, you will be able to see.
You will see an example of a balcony or a window to the three pyramids.
And of course, we provided a view on the day that separates the museum from the pyramids.
So, no one ever sees something that reaches a certain height through it.
You will find the three pyramids right in front of you in a very beautiful scene.
From the window of the museum project in Greater Cairo.
One can see the three pyramids of Giza in a very magnificent way.
We are, of course, located in the west as a museum, while they are in the east.
So, it feels like you are seeing the sun and things related to the sun.
It overlooks the west from the east where it is located.
So, for the visitor who wants to reach the Grand Egyptian Museum.

From the Japanese agency, and they were linking it to my signing of our project.
